title: 112_s3595
content: Exception from passive loss rules for investments in high technology research small business pass-thru entities. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to exclude high technology research activities from passive activity rules for small business pass-thru entities. This applies to domestic pass-thru entities where more than 75 percent of the activities are high technology research. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to exclude high technology research activities from passive activity rules for small business pass-thru entities. If more than 75 percent of the entity's expenditures are in connection with qualified research or more than 50 percent of the expenditures constitute qualified research, it qualifies for the exclusion. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to exclude high technology research activities from passive activity rules for small business pass-thru entities. To qualify for the exclusion, the entity must have more than 75 percent of its expenditures in connection with qualified research or more than 50 percent of its expenditures must constitute qualified research. Additionally, the entity must be a small business with aggregate gross assets not exceeding $150,000,000. The term 'aggregate gross assets' is defined in section 1202(d)(2). Section 197 intangibles used directly in research are excluded from the calculation of aggregate gross assets. Cash from the sale of equity interests is also not included in the calculation. The determination of aggregate gross assets excludes certain interests if the entity's assets do not exceed $150,000,000 plus 25 percent of the assets before the sale. Sales of equity interests under the same plan or arrangement, or with the purpose of increasing cash, exceeding $150,000,000, are treated as a single sale. The $150,000,000 amount is subject to inflation adjustment after 2013. The dollar amounts in clauses (i) and (ii) of clause (iii) will be increased by the cost of living adjustment for the calendar year, with rounding to the nearest $100,000. Capital expenditures are considered for tax purposes. The text discusses capital expenditures for tax purposes, clarifying that such expenditures should not be excluded based on being chargeable to a capital account. It also defines a pass-thru entity and outlines aggregation rules for certain entities treated as a single employer. Activities not engaged in for profit and economic substance rules do not apply to disallow losses, deductions, and credits of a high technology research small business pass-thru entity due to losses incurred by the entity. Material participation is not required for certain research-related deductions and credits of high technology research small business pass-thru entities for determining alternative minimum tax. (1) Deduction for research and experimental expenditures.-- Paragraph (2) of section 56(b) of the Code is amended to exempt high technology research small business pass-thru entities from certain deductions under section 174(a). (2) Allowance of certain research-related credits.-- Section 38(c)(4) of the Code is amended to include new clauses related to research credits. The new clause allows for credits related to high technology research small business pass-thru entities. An exception is made to the limitation on pass-thru of research credit for these entities. The effective date for these amendments is for taxable years beginning after the enactment of the Act.
